dublin_core.dcvalue: OBJECTIVE We conducted a naturalistic study to examine negative affect and dissociative experiences as antecedents to binge episodes METHOD Using handheld computers 33 women with bulimic syndromes provided ongoing self reports on eating behaviors affects and dissociative experiences over 7 to 29 day intervals RESULTS Multilevel modeling analyses indicated that negative affect and dissociation were elevated prior to binge episodes In addition antecedent effects of dissociation on bingeing were independent of those attributable to negative affect CONCLUSION Our results are consistent with models of binge eating that assign a causal role to negative mood and altered self awareness As such our findings imply that binge eating is a multiply determined behavior linked to diverse cognitive and affective processes
The International journal of eating disorders
Binge antecedents in bulimic syndromes: an examination of dissociation and negative affect.
